lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: To-morrow is the joyful day, Audrey; to-morrow will we be married.

lines.speaker: audrey
lines.text: I do desire it with all my heart; and I hope it is no dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world. Here comes two of the banished duke's pages.

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: By my troth, well met. Come, sit, sit, and a song.

lines.speaker: second page
lines.text: We are for you: sit i' the middle.

lines.speaker: first page
lines.text: Shall we clap into't roundly, without hawking or spitting or saying we are hoarse, which are the only prologues to a bad voice?

lines.speaker: second page
lines.text: I'faith, i'faith; and both in a tune, like two gipsies on a horse. SONG. It was a lover and his lass, With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino, That o'er the green corn-field did pass In the spring time, the only pretty ring time, When birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding: Sweet lovers love the spring. Between the acres of the rye, With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino These pretty country folks would lie, In spring time,  and c. This carol they began that hour, With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino, How that a life was but a flower In spring time,  and c. And therefore take the present time, With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino; For love is crowned with the prime In spring time,  and c.

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great matter in the ditty, yet the note was very untuneable.

lines.speaker: first page
lines.text: You are deceived, sir: we kept time, we lost not our time.

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: By my troth, yes; I count it but time lost to hear such a foolish song. God be wi' you; and God mend your voices! Come, Audrey.
